Who killed the electric car?

Raleigh ranks high in readiness for plug-in vehicles

Photo by Aaron Landry
  • By Rebecca Seawell
  • reesenews assistant editor
Feb. 16 3:26 pm
  • 9042no commentshttp%3A%2F%2Freesenews.org%2F2011%2F02%2F16%2Fwho-killed-the-electric-car%2F9042%2FWho+killed+the+electric+car%3F2011-02-16+20%3A26%3A06Rebecca+Seawellhttp%3A%2F%2Freesenews.org%2F%3Fp%3D9042
  • E-mail
  • Print

Do you like this story?

Sources

  • John Richardson, Chapel Hill Sustainability Officer
  • Nelson Daniels, Raleigh Senior Sustainability Technician
  • Don Crohan, vice president, Triangle Electric Auto Association

TRIANGLE
In 1900, roughly one-third of cars on the street were electric. Even Henry Ford’s wife is documented to have driven an electric car.

Electric vehicles have made several brief appearances in the past century, both in the early 1900s and in the early 1990s, when the public witnessed emergence of vehicles such as the GM EV-1, Honda EV Plus and Ford Ranger EV.

Now, with the release of the Nissan Leaf and Chevy Volt, electric vehicles have received another chance to break into the automobile industry for good.

In anticipation of their release, Raleigh and other metro areas across the country have participated in Project Get Ready. An initiative of the Rocky Mountain Institute, Project Get Ready is a nonprofit that aims to prepare cities for plug-in electric vehicles, also known as PEVs.

In a recent study by the organization, Raleigh ranked in the highest category of leaders regarding readiness for PEVs in a survey of the 50 largest metro areas.

The report took into account consumer environment, infrastructure readiness and the city’s operating environment.

But due to lack of necessary infrastructure and technical issues with the vehicles themselves, attempts to successfully introduce mass-produced electric vehicles have been unsuccessful, said Don Drohan, the vice president of the Triangle Electric Auto Association.

“It would be the smartest, most efficient, wisest move towards transportation if properly handled,” Crohan said.

With the help of federal grants, Raleigh has installed three charging stations since November 2010, and the city plans to introduce 20 to 30 more in the coming year, said the city’s senior sustainability technician Nelson Daniels.

Daniels said that Raleigh began its partnership with the project in 2009, when the city announced its participation in the project NC Get Ready.

While Chapel Hill currently does not have any public charging stations for PEVs, John Richardson, sustainability officer for Chapel Hill, said the town is considering installing them in public parking lots in the future.

“We’re still interested in looking at ways to explore EV technology and explore the stations themselves,” Richardson said, adding that Chapel Hill has been participating in discussions with initiatives like Project Get Ready and its partner, Advanced Energy.

Chapel Hill is no stranger to electric vehicles, Richardson said. The town purchased several Ford Ranger EVs for town use before Ford stopped production in 2002 and recalled the vehicles.

Currently, Chapel Hill uses 16 hybrid electric buses, a number of hybrid electrics and a purely electric neighborhood electric vehicle used by the town’s Parking Services Division.

But even with recent developments, the future for electric cars is far from certain.

Crohan said that his organization’s reaction to the release of EVs such as the Nissan Leaf and Chevy Volt is “very cautious.”

The newly released EVs first need to prove themselves as reliable, efficient and financially worthwhile before the Triangle Electric Auto Association recommends them to consumers, Crohan said.

“If you were to say to me, ‘Should I buy this car?’, I would say it’s too soon to tell,” he said.

The finances are already proving to be an issue — consumers can buy a new 2011 BMW 1 Series for the same sticker price as the Chevy Volt, and taxpayers are paying part of the price.

The Volt costs $41,000 before a $7,500 credit, lowering the cost to $33,500 per unit.

Crohan said he wonders if the Volt is worth the high price to buyers and taxpayers, especially since it is unknown what the cost of charging at a public station will be and how much future maintenance will cost.

“We want them to prove themselves as we would with any other technology out there,” Crohan said. “Even if it was a toaster.”

This article was reported as part of the J253 Reporting and News Writing course at UNC’s School of Journalism and Mass Communication.
